unnormalised: ## Finding My Balance: A Journey Through Ayurveda Treatments
normalised: ## Finding My Balance: A Journey Through Ayurveda Treatments

unnormalised: My journey into Ayurveda began somewhat unexpectedly. I was feeling constantly drained, the relentless pace of Mumbai life leaving me perpetually exhausted. Doc told me to "slow down," but that's easier said than done, isn't it? A friend, Priya, suggested I explore Ayurveda. She swore by it after a retreat in Kerala last year. Honestly, I was skeptical, but desperate times...

unnormalised: I started with a consultation at a small Ayurvedic clinic in Andheri, run by Dr. Sharma. He spent a good hour just talking to me, understanding my lifestyle, diet, and stress levels. Turns out, according to Ayurveda, I’m primarily Pitta, which explains my fiery temperament and susceptibility to heat. He recommended a Panchakarma treatment to detoxify my system and restore balance.

unnormalised: Panchakarma, I learned, is no walk in the park. It's a series of therapies, from Abhyanga (oil massage) to Shirodhara (oil pouring on the forehead). My first Shirodhara session was on 10/10/2024. I was initially apprehensive about warm oil dripping onto my head for 45 minutes, but the sensation was incredibly soothing. It's difficult to describe the peace that washed over me. I practically floated out of the clinic afterwards.

unnormalised: Over the next week, I followed Dr. Sharma’s diet plan, which meant saying goodbye to my beloved spicy chaat and hello to khichdi and herbal teas. It wasn't always easy, especially when the aroma of samosas wafted from the nearby street stall at 16:00 hrs. But I persevered.
normalised: Over the next week, I followed Doctor Sharma’s diet plan, which meant saying goodbye to my beloved spicy chaat and hello to khichdi and herbal teas. It wasn't always easy, especially when the aroma of samosas wafted from the nearby street stall at four p m. But I persevered.

unnormalised: Beyond the treatments, Dr. Sharma emphasized the importance of lifestyle changes: waking up early (ideally before 06:00 hrs), practicing yoga, and incorporating meditation into my daily routine. He also suggested incorporating triphala churna before bedtime. It's been about a month since I started, and I’m already feeling a significant difference. My energy levels are up, I’m sleeping better, and I'm handling stress more effectively. I even managed to squeeze in a quick getaway to Lonavala last weekend, a mini-retreat of my own! Ayurveda isn't a quick fix, but a journey towards holistic well-being. It’s about understanding your body, embracing nature's wisdom, and finding your own personal equilibrium. I'm just getting started, and I’m excited to see where this path leads.
